attributes.title: Participatory Measurement, Monitoring, and Management of Groundwater in Northeast Brazil

q1.value: Participatory Measurement, Monitoring, and Management of Groundwater in Northeast Brazil

q2.value: Alicia Cooperman | Alexandra Richey | Brigitte Seim

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: This pre-analysis plan outlines a field experiment entitled "Participatory Measurement, Monitoring, and Management of Groundwater in Northeast Brazil" and outlines the theory, hypotheses, data collection and empirical strategies that will be used to analyze the results. This field experiment is one of six studies in the Metaketa-III Natural Resource Governance Project sponsored by Evidence in Governance and Politics (EGAP) to study community monitoring of governance of forests and water. This project fits into the larger strategy set out by the Evidence in Governance and Politics (EGAP) Metaketa III Initiative, which looks at whether resource use and management improve in the presence of community monitoring. As highlighted by Olson (1965), rationally-driven individuals will not necessarily cooperate in situations where collective-action would lead to socially optimum outcomes, thus common-pool resource problems also require monitoring, enforcement, and credible commitments. Using strategies consolidated in the literature to improve management of commons Ostrom (2000), we provide evidence on the relationship of community monitoring and groundwater management.

q16.value: There are four harmonized hypotheses regarding the effect of T1 on resource use, satisfaction with water supply, water consumption costs, and water status awareness. For T2, there are four additional (non-harmonized) hypotheses regarding the effect of T2 on collective action capacity, satisfaction with community association performance, attendance at community association meetings, and awareness of water use planning. There are three harmonized hypotheses regarding intermediate outcomes: perception of scrutiny, perception of user interest, and perception of likelihood of sanctions. There are five harmonized moderator hypotheses: severity (increase effects), collective action capacity (increase effects), organization capacity (increase effects), population (decrease effects), compliance (increase effects). We also have seven additional moderator hypotheses: association participation (increase effects), political embeddedness (decrease effects), water management structures (increase effects), gender (greater effects among women), community association membership (increase effects), livestock ownership (increase effects), SISAR membership (increase effects).

q17.value: The study will evaluate the impact of two programs that enhance community capacity to manage groundwater resources. There are three treatment groups: Treatment 1, Treatment 2, and Control. The common treatment program, in both Treatment 1 and 2, uses community workshops to facilitate a participatory approach to groundwater management and community-based collection and dissemination of data on groundwater levels and use. The additional treatment arm, in Treatment 2, adds a module where community water committees work with households to create water use plans. Our field experiment takes place in Northeast Brazil and focuses on management of groundwater accessed via wells. The Northeast is the poorest region of Brazil and is also Brazil's semi-arid, and thus driest, region. In a two-stage sampling strategy, we randomly selected 120 communities from 10 municipalities. These 120 communities will be randomized into blocks of three. Within each block of three, one community will receive T1, one will receive T2, and one will be in the control group. A baseline and endline survey provides measures of the individual outcomes, which will be analyzed in a difference-in-differences framework. The community-level resource use outcomes will be calculated from electricity records associated with the community wells and monthly precipitation data, which will be analyzed in a difference-in-differences framework.

attributes.title: Unequal enforcement: How perceived ethnicity and written English proficiency affect welfare agencies’ responses

q1.value: Unequal enforcement: How perceived ethnicity and written English proficiency affect welfare agencies’ responses

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: Numerous studies have revealed systematic inequalities in government-individual relationships and access to state services and resources (Ayres and Siegelman 1995, Butler and Broockman 2011, Doleac and Stein 2013, Giulietti and Vlassopoulos 2015, Milkman et al. 2014, Turner et al. 2013, White et al. 2015). Other research has found less evidence of racial/ethnic discrimination in access to government programs for the poor (Einstein and Glick 2017). The present study tests for discrimination in online systems for public reporting of suspected fraud in the Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP), examining the effects of race/ethnicity and written English proficiency.

q16.value: H1: There will be no significant differences in response rates to reports from different parties. H2: Reports from Latinas will have lower response rates than those from whites, independent of English proficiency. H3A: Reports from Latinas will have higher response rates than those from whites, independent of English proficiency. H3B (heterogeneous effects): Reports from Latinas will have especially elevated response rates in states with greater residential racial segregation. H4: Reports from lower-English proficiency individuals will have lower response rates than higher-English proficiency individuals, independent of race/ethnicity. H5: Reports from lower-English proficiency Latinas will have particularly low response rates. H6A: Reports from lower-English proficiency Latinas will have particularly high response rates. H6B (heterogeneous effects): Reports from lower-proficiency Latinas will have especially elevated response rates in states with greater residential racial segregation.

q17.value: We will create (a) two dummies (white/non-white) & (proficient/non-proficient); (b) a continuous variable measuring before response; and (c) a continuous variable measuring response length. We will first conduct simple OLS & binomial models. We will also calculate the Average Treatment Effect (ATE) using a simple difference of means approach. Specifically, if W is white, NW is non-white, P is proficient, and NP is non-proficient, we will measure the ATEs in terms of: Q(W) = E[Y (W ) – Y(NW)] Q(P) = E[Y (P) – Y(NP)] In addition to average effects across the entire sample, we also posit hypotheses on heterogeneous treatment effects, in which the effects of concerns about ethnicity/proficiency vary depending on the variables discussed in the previous section. As controls, we will measure segregation using Licher et al (2016).

attributes.title: United We Stand, Divided We Fall? How Signals of Activist Unity Affect Attraction to Social Movements

q1.value: United We Stand, Divided We Fall? How Signals of Activist Unity Affect Attraction to Social Movements

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

registration_responses.q1: United We Stand, Divided We Fall? How Signals of Activist Unity Affect Attraction to Social Movements
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q2.value: Sean Webeck | Sean Nicholson-Crotty | Jill Nicholson-Crotty

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: In recent years the City of Flint, Michigan has been dealing with problems associated with lead in the city's drinking water supply. We situate this problem in the context of a scholarly discussion about the use of performance information. Specifically, we use publicly available data from Kansas City's KC Stat Dashboard to better understand how people respond to managing a sensitive public issue, such as lead poisoning. We are interested in learning which drives an assessment of performance more--actual performance data or stories about the poor performance of other, related organizations. We are interested in these questions: 1. How do people assess the management of a program with historical performance data for multiple years? 2. How do people assess public sector performance in the context of a "crisis" policy issue? 3. When people are asked to make a performance comparison, how closely do performance stories approximate performance metrics in how individuals process government performance? 4. Does public sector performance data moderate a story about public sector performance or, do stories about public sector performance moderate how individuals respond to performance data?

q16.value: 1 - Those who see historical performance data will assess the management of a public sector program differently than those who only see the most recent year of data. 2 - Stories about performance--even if not about the performance of the organization in question--influence the way individuals process performance information. 3. The presence of data will moderate the influence of stories in how individuals process performance information. 4. Asking individuals to think about the performance of another (similar) organization will reduce uncertainty by creating a reference point for the information they are being asked to assess.

q17.value: We will use ANOVA and other post-hoc assessment techniques to determine any differences in the assessed performance of individuals randomly assigned to different treatment groups.

q23.value: We are adding this experiment as an amendment to an already accepted IRB. It will be delivered in a survey with some other experiments already accepted in that IRB protocol.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to any research activities

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher access to outcome data

q15.value: The effect of candidate's religiosity on voters' evaluation of the candidate as well as the voters' intention to vote for the candidate has not been studied in an experimental context independent of the candidate's policy position, party identification and other characteristics. Investigating the effect of candidate religiosity independent of other factors is especially important in the context of Turkey, which is deeply mobilized along the religious-secular dimension.

q16.value: Our main quantity of interest is vote intention for a hypothetical candidate whose religiosity is randomly manipulated across respondents. Other quantities of interest are respondents' evaluation of the candidate such as the candidate's corruption, trustworthiness, voter's overall impression of the candidate and which party the respondent thinks the candidate is from. Our main hypothesis is that religiosity has a positive overall impact on these outcomes. We also expect heterogenous treatment effects, that there will be more positive effects among more religious respondents.

q17.value: We employ a factorial design, where we manipulate 6 different characteristics of the hypothetical candidate. Hence, we have 2^6=64 different videos. Each respondent is shown a single video and is asked to answer the outcome questions mentioned in part C2. These 6 characteristics are religiosity, age, political experience, occupation/education, and stance on 2 different policy issues.

attributes.title: Identifying the Effects of Fox News

q1.value: Identifying the Effects of Fox News

q2.value: Kimberly Gross | Ethan Porter | Thomas J. Wood

q8.value: Registration prior to assignment of treatment

q15.value: Since its inception in the mid-1990s, scholars have attempted to identify the effects of Fox News on political outcomes. Research has demonstrated the cable channel has conservatizing effects on both the mass public and elites (e.g. DellaVigna and Kaplan 2007; Enamorado and Clinton 2012; Martin and Yurukoglu 2014). Our study extends this work, attempting to provide more credible measures of the Fox News Effect, to identify more precisely the relationship between the amount of exposure to Fox News programming and any resulting attitudinal change, and to identify who is most susceptible to partisan media effects. Our approach is distinguished by its avoidance of the pitfalls that confront many studies of media effects. Rather than rely on stylized lab settings or as-if experimental designs, we administer a cost-efficient field experiment on the media in question. Specifically, we focus on the “dosage effects” of Fox News. Does Fox New programming have a conservatizing effect? How much exposure to Fox News opinion programming does it take to change political beliefs and attitudes? The most recent research indicates that the answer may be stunningly small. According to Martin and Yurukoglu (2017), among those who were randomly exposed to watching only an additional 2.5 minutes of Fox News per week, Republican vote share increased by 0.3%. If only 2.5 minutes of random exposure can have an identifiable effect on outcomes, what about random exposure to larger amounts of time viewing Fox News programming? Thus our study seeks to answer the following questions: Does exposure to Fox News influence evaluations of parties and political leaders? Will individuals begin to adopt the frames utilized by the network in its coverage of policies and issues? Will they be persuaded to move in a conservative direction on those issues highlighted in the content viewed? Does more exposure in fact produce larger effects? Who is most influenced? Or do we actually uncover little evidence for persuasive effects of partisan news programming? To answer these questions, we will implement an encouragement design, whereby participants are randomly encouraged and incentivized to watch 30 minutes of the Fox News Channel program “Tucker Carlson Tonight” for one night or three nights or to watch a Food Network for 30 minutes one night. [fn] Encouragement designs are used frequently in medical research or research in which it is unfeasible or unethical to deny or force access to treatment. (For a review, consult Sovey and Green 2011.) In our case, while we cannot force people in the real world to watch Fox News, we can encourage them to, and we can offer them compensation for doing so. This approach allows us to avoid the identification problems related to self-selection into partisan media that come with observational designs. With random assignment we can study partisan media while overcoming people’s propensity to self-select into ideologically consistent media. At the same time, we are ensuring that individuals are exposed to media content under realistic conditions, an improvement over the external validity issues raised by laboratory experiments of media effects. [/fn] A growing literature has focused on the effects of partisan news, a literature that is embedded in the more general literature on media effects. That wider literature suggests that significant persuasive media effects may be small to non-existent. Other work argues that with the rise of partisan media and selective exposure media effects may be substantial but self-canceling in the aggregate. Partisan media, of the sort embodied by Fox News and MSNBC, may play an especially large role in canceling out media effects (Bennett and Iyengar 2008). If each side has its own praise chorus, and citizens only acquire information from their co-partisan sources, then overall media effects will hardly be discernible. There is reason to expect partisan media does matter and that the effects may depend on initial partisan perspectives. In a series of lab experiments, Levendusky (2013) finds partisan media to have polarizing effects, with partisans becoming more entrenched in their beliefs. He also finds that these polarizing effects survive for several days after initial exposure. With survey evidence from 2008, Dilliplane (2014) shows that partisan media can affect vote choice as well; by her account, partisan media exposure reinforces party vote choice. However, Arceneaux and Johnson (2013) suggest that partisan media effects are limited by self-selection and media choice. Given a choice, most individuals prefer entertainment and other programming to partisan media with those most likely to be influenced more likely to avoid news generally and partisan news in particular. They also find that when forced to watch cross partisan channels individuals are not persuaded but rather dig in on their initial views. Consistent with motivated reasoning, their work suggests that those exposed to partisan content consistent with their predispositions will be reinforced in their perspectives but those exposed to a counter-partisan channel may discount that framing (Arceneaux and Johnson, 2013). This and other research (Zaller, 1992) would lead us to expect that those who are less informed and weaker partisan should be more susceptible to partisan media effects. Other prior work (Gross, Porter, Wood 2016) has uncovered effects of partisan news (Fox News Channel and MSNBC) post-debate spin on evaluations of Clinton and Trump debate performance following the first presidential debate of the 2016 election. Those who watched post-debate coverage on Fox were more positively disposed toward Trump and less positively disposed toward Clinton. One week later, they uncover effects among moderate partisans with negative effects on Clinton evaluations among weak Democrats who watched the Fox commentary and positive effects on Clinton evaluations among weak Republicans who watched the MSNBC commentary. Prior research into Fox News has claimed that the network, with its demonstrated partisan leanings, is capable of generating substantively large political effects. DellaVigna and Kaplan (2007) exploit the gradual dissemination of Fox News across the United States between 1996 and 2000 to find that the channel resulted in a 0.7% surge in support for the Republican Party in the 2000 presidential election, compared to 1996, in towns that were airing Fox News by the later date. More recently, Martin and Yurukoglu (2017) have leveraged the random placement of Fox News on the proverbial cable dial to find that a miniscule amount of random additional exposure to the network increases Republican vote share by 0.3%. While both estimates are credible and well-identified, they are nonetheless limited, in that they are built on statistical assumptions that may not be true. For example, there is reason to doubt that the placement of Fox News on the cable dial is as random as Martin and Yurukoglu claim. Both studies were designed to mimic the robustness of an experiment, without actually implementing one. In contrast, our study would constitute an actual field experiment about Fox News, focused on how Americans change their views in real time because of exposure to the network. We expect to find effects of Fox News on evaluations of Trump and the political parties. We also expect Fox New will have a conservatizing effect on opinion on those issues highlighted in their programming. If our expectations are not met, and exposure does not change minds to the degree we anticipate, this would suggest that prior research has relied on faulty assumptions that have exaggerated the impact of the network. On the other hand, if indeed we do detect what we expect--that Fox News can change minds--we will be able to show how much Fox News viewers must watch before their minds are changed. Either way, we believe that this project would mark a significant advancement in the study of Fox News specifically and media effects more broadly.

q16.value: Our initial recruitment will be done through a short survey on Mechanical Turk that will be used to identify individuals who have access to cable and to gather relevant demographic and background data on subjects. From this, we will randomly assign subjects to one of three conditions. In the Maximum Dosage condition, subjects will be encouraged to watch the Fox News Program Tucker Carlson Tonight for thirty minutes for three separate weekday nights. In the Minimal Dosage condition, subjects will be encouraged to watch Tucker Carlson Tonight for thirty minutes for one night. There will also be a control group that will watch a Food Network program airing at the same time as Tucker Carlson for thirty minutes for one night. Our main dependent variables are measured with a survey on day three for the maximum dosage condition which coincides with the day that the minimum dosage condition and control group are assigned to watch. Prior work shows Fox News to generally provide a conservative slant (Martin and Yurukoglu, 2017; Aday, 2010). Thus, we expect the effect of exposure to Fox News opinion programing will be to move individuals in a conservative direction in terms of their attitudes and opinions. Because the nature and size of effects would likely depend on the specific content that airs during the nights we field the study, our study will include careful analysis of each nights broadcast to measure political context. Our observation of Tucker Carlson Tonight suggests that the show includes content that regularly critiques democrats, generally offers support for republicans and the administration, and offers conservative perspectives on policy including consistent support for restrictive immigration policy. HYPOTHESES H1 Fox News Conservatizing Effects on Attitudes and Opinions While we anticipate heterogeneous effects as noted below, we expect overall main effects of Fox News based on the prior work demonstrating effects of Fox News on republican vote. Specifically because of the conservative nature of commentary on Fox News’ opinion programming like Tucker Carlson Tonight which fairly consistently critiques Democrats, supports Republicans and the administration, and offers conservative perspectives on policies like immigration we hypothesize that: H1A. Exposure to Fox News will influence evaluations of leaders and parties We expect that exposure to Fox News programming will lead individuals to feel more positively disposed toward Donald Trump and the Republican Party and more negatively disposed toward the Democratic Party. H1B. Exposure to Fox News will cause individuals to bring their policy views closer in line with those espoused on the programs they view. We expect that exposure to Fox News programming will lead individuals to express move conservative views toward the policies that are a focus of the programming watched (e.g. more support for restrictive immigration policy, more skepticism toward the Mueller investigation if those topics are a focus of the program on night of study). H1C. Exposure to Fox News will make individuals say the scope of government should be restricted. Given the general conservative slant of Carlson’s program, we expect exposure to Fox News programming will lead individuals to be more likely to say the scope of government should be restricted. H2. Dosage Effects We expect Fox News effects will be larger for those assigned to watch more Fox programming compared to those assigned to watch less Fox programming. H3. Heterogeneous Effects To understand who is effected by Fox News exposure, we also examine our effects separately by strength of partisanship and racial resentment. We have some expectation of differential influence based on how the content interacts with an individual’s prior views. Specifically, we expect stronger partisans will either be encountering information consistent with their perspectives and thus it is merely reinforcing or encountering counter-partisan information which motivated reasoning may lead them to reject. This will limit effects among strong partisans. Thus we expect it is those with weak partisan attachments and independents who are most influenced. H3A. Fox News Effects will be strongest among those with weak partisan attachments. Based on our own prior work and Zaller, we expect that those with weaker partisan attachments and independents will be more open to persuasion. Thus we expect Fox News Effects to be stronger among those with weak partisan attachments. H3B. Fox News Effects will be stronger among those high on racial resentment. The implicit racialized rhetoric that often see on Carlson’s program should be more persuasive among those high on racial resentment. We would particularly expect this if immigration is a key issue in the content during our study.

q17.value: Participants in our study will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions: Maximum Dosage Fox News Condition where watch Tucker Carlson Tonight for 30 minutes each night for three nights in a row; Minimum Dosage Fox News Condition where watch Tucker Carlson Tonight for 30 minutes one night and a Control Group where watch the Food Network Program Chopped for 30 minutes one night. Those in the Minimum Dosage and Control groups watch on what will be evening three for the Maximum Dosage condition. All groups then get the survey measuring our key outcome variables shortly after treatment that evening. To assess effects, our survey will ask participants their feelings about President Trump, the Republican and Democratic Parties, and their positions on a variety of policy issues (gun control, immigration, taxes, trade, and healthcare). We will include additional specific questions on issues that are the focus on the news cycle at the time of our study (specific questions decided on the day of the treatment to take advantage of the issues covered by the program in the week/on the day we administer the study). In addition, we will evaluate compliance with the treatment including questions on whether they watched on their assigned channel and a comprehension question about content that aired in the last five minutes of the programming they watched. [fn] Those in the maximum dosage condition will be sent a survey each night of the study. On nights 1 and 2 they will get only a very short survey focused on compliance evaluation.[/fn] By comparing responses of those assigned to watch more Fox News with those assigned to watch less Fox News, and by comparing responses of those assigned to watch any Fox News with those not assigned to watch any Fox, we will have estimates of the Fox News Effect in general, and the extent to which the effect is moderated by dosage amount. Our expectations, based on prior work, are that any exposure to Fox News will cause subjects to feel more positively disposed toward Donald Trump and the Republican Party, more negatively disposed toward the Democratic Party and will bring their policy views closer in line with those espoused by the network. We expect that the effects will be larger for those assigned to watch more Fox News, compared to those assigned to watch less. We also examine heterogeneous effects based on strength of partisanship and racial resentment. We expect stronger effects among weak partisans and independents and among those higher in racial resentment. We will measure effects both in an Intent-to-Treat framework, whereby we do not account for compliance, and as a function of compliance, where we focus only on those we believe successfully complied with their assignment. The size of the effects will likely depend on the content that airs the nights we field the study, which of course we cannot control. To account for this we will have a larger battery of policy questions related to the issues featured that evening added once we know the content of the program. Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants Participants will be U.S. residents age 18 and older who are workers on Mechanical Turk who report access to both the Fox News Channel and the Food Network in our wave 1 recruitment survey and who agree to take part in the study. Our target sample size is 450 per condition. To reach this sample size we will initially recruit 3000 participants with our recruitment survey (to ensure we have enough individuals with access to cable who then agree to participate when invited into the study). We stratify on Party ID before random assignment to condition. Participants are recruited through MTurk, encouraged to uptake the media treatments through messages inviting those randomly assigned to a given treatment to participate in the study and providing details on their treatment assignment. The treatments are effectively administered in participants own homes or wherever they access cable. The surveys assessing compliance and measuring our key outcome variables hosted on the Qualtrics online survey platform and the invitation to complete the survey is sent approximately 30 minutes after end of the treatment assignment. Additional information including measurement of outcome variables (survey questions), statistical analyses, modeling and hypotheses testing is in the attached pre-analysis plan.

registration_responses.q1: Identifying the Effects of Fox News
registration_responses.q2: Kimberly Gross | Ethan Porter | Thomas J. Wood
registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to assignment of treatment
registration_responses.q15: Since its inception in the mid-1990s, scholars have attempted to identify the effects of Fox News on political outcomes. Research has demonstrated the cable channel has conservatizing effects on both the mass public and elites (e.g. DellaVigna and Kaplan 2007; Enamorado and Clinton 2012; Martin and Yurukoglu 2014). Our study extends this work, attempting to provide more credible measures of the Fox News Effect, to identify more precisely the relationship between the amount of exposure to Fox News programming and any resulting attitudinal change, and to identify who is most susceptible to partisan media effects. Our approach is distinguished by its avoidance of the pitfalls that confront many studies of media effects. Rather than rely on stylized lab settings or as-if experimental designs, we administer a cost-efficient field experiment on the media in question. Specifically, we focus on the “dosage effects” of Fox News. Does Fox New programming have a conservatizing effect? How much exposure to Fox News opinion programming does it take to change political beliefs and attitudes? The most recent research indicates that the answer may be stunningly small. According to Martin and Yurukoglu (2017), among those who were randomly exposed to watching only an additional 2.5 minutes of Fox News per week, Republican vote share increased by 0.3%. If only 2.5 minutes of random exposure can have an identifiable effect on outcomes, what about random exposure to larger amounts of time viewing Fox News programming? Thus our study seeks to answer the following questions: Does exposure to Fox News influence evaluations of parties and political leaders? Will individuals begin to adopt the frames utilized by the network in its coverage of policies and issues? Will they be persuaded to move in a conservative direction on those issues highlighted in the content viewed? Does more exposure in fact produce larger effects? Who is most influenced? Or do we actually uncover little evidence for persuasive effects of partisan news programming? To answer these questions, we will implement an encouragement design, whereby participants are randomly encouraged and incentivized to watch 30 minutes of the Fox News Channel program “Tucker Carlson Tonight” for one night or three nights or to watch a Food Network for 30 minutes one night. [fn] Encouragement designs are used frequently in medical research or research in which it is unfeasible or unethical to deny or force access to treatment. (For a review, consult Sovey and Green 2011.) In our case, while we cannot force people in the real world to watch Fox News, we can encourage them to, and we can offer them compensation for doing so. This approach allows us to avoid the identification problems related to self-selection into partisan media that come with observational designs. With random assignment we can study partisan media while overcoming people’s propensity to self-select into ideologically consistent media. At the same time, we are ensuring that individuals are exposed to media content under realistic conditions, an improvement over the external validity issues raised by laboratory experiments of media effects. [/fn] A growing literature has focused on the effects of partisan news, a literature that is embedded in the more general literature on media effects. That wider literature suggests that significant persuasive media effects may be small to non-existent. Other work argues that with the rise of partisan media and selective exposure media effects may be substantial but self-canceling in the aggregate. Partisan media, of the sort embodied by Fox News and MSNBC, may play an especially large role in canceling out media effects (Bennett and Iyengar 2008). If each side has its own praise chorus, and citizens only acquire information from their co-partisan sources, then overall media effects will hardly be discernible. There is reason to expect partisan media does matter and that the effects may depend on initial partisan perspectives. In a series of lab experiments, Levendusky (2013) finds partisan media to have polarizing effects, with partisans becoming more entrenched in their beliefs. He also finds that these polarizing effects survive for several days after initial exposure. With survey evidence from 2008, Dilliplane (2014) shows that partisan media can affect vote choice as well; by her account, partisan media exposure reinforces party vote choice. However, Arceneaux and Johnson (2013) suggest that partisan media effects are limited by self-selection and media choice. Given a choice, most individuals prefer entertainment and other programming to partisan media with those most likely to be influenced more likely to avoid news generally and partisan news in particular. They also find that when forced to watch cross partisan channels individuals are not persuaded but rather dig in on their initial views. Consistent with motivated reasoning, their work suggests that those exposed to partisan content consistent with their predispositions will be reinforced in their perspectives but those exposed to a counter-partisan channel may discount that framing (Arceneaux and Johnson, 2013). This and other research (Zaller, 1992) would lead us to expect that those who are less informed and weaker partisan should be more susceptible to partisan media effects. Other prior work (Gross, Porter, Wood 2016) has uncovered effects of partisan news (Fox News Channel and MSNBC) post-debate spin on evaluations of Clinton and Trump debate performance following the first presidential debate of the 2016 election. Those who watched post-debate coverage on Fox were more positively disposed toward Trump and less positively disposed toward Clinton. One week later, they uncover effects among moderate partisans with negative effects on Clinton evaluations among weak Democrats who watched the Fox commentary and positive effects on Clinton evaluations among weak Republicans who watched the MSNBC commentary. Prior research into Fox News has claimed that the network, with its demonstrated partisan leanings, is capable of generating substantively large political effects. DellaVigna and Kaplan (2007) exploit the gradual dissemination of Fox News across the United States between 1996 and 2000 to find that the channel resulted in a 0.7% surge in support for the Republican Party in the 2000 presidential election, compared to 1996, in towns that were airing Fox News by the later date. More recently, Martin and Yurukoglu (2017) have leveraged the random placement of Fox News on the proverbial cable dial to find that a miniscule amount of random additional exposure to the network increases Republican vote share by 0.3%. While both estimates are credible and well-identified, they are nonetheless limited, in that they are built on statistical assumptions that may not be true. For example, there is reason to doubt that the placement of Fox News on the cable dial is as random as Martin and Yurukoglu claim. Both studies were designed to mimic the robustness of an experiment, without actually implementing one. In contrast, our study would constitute an actual field experiment about Fox News, focused on how Americans change their views in real time because of exposure to the network. We expect to find effects of Fox News on evaluations of Trump and the political parties. We also expect Fox New will have a conservatizing effect on opinion on those issues highlighted in their programming. If our expectations are not met, and exposure does not change minds to the degree we anticipate, this would suggest that prior research has relied on faulty assumptions that have exaggerated the impact of the network. On the other hand, if indeed we do detect what we expect--that Fox News can change minds--we will be able to show how much Fox News viewers must watch before their minds are changed. Either way, we believe that this project would mark a significant advancement in the study of Fox News specifically and media effects more broadly.
registration_responses.q16: Our initial recruitment will be done through a short survey on Mechanical Turk that will be used to identify individuals who have access to cable and to gather relevant demographic and background data on subjects. From this, we will randomly assign subjects to one of three conditions. In the Maximum Dosage condition, subjects will be encouraged to watch the Fox News Program Tucker Carlson Tonight for thirty minutes for three separate weekday nights. In the Minimal Dosage condition, subjects will be encouraged to watch Tucker Carlson Tonight for thirty minutes for one night. There will also be a control group that will watch a Food Network program airing at the same time as Tucker Carlson for thirty minutes for one night. Our main dependent variables are measured with a survey on day three for the maximum dosage condition which coincides with the day that the minimum dosage condition and control group are assigned to watch. Prior work shows Fox News to generally provide a conservative slant (Martin and Yurukoglu, 2017; Aday, 2010). Thus, we expect the effect of exposure to Fox News opinion programing will be to move individuals in a conservative direction in terms of their attitudes and opinions. Because the nature and size of effects would likely depend on the specific content that airs during the nights we field the study, our study will include careful analysis of each nights broadcast to measure political context. Our observation of Tucker Carlson Tonight suggests that the show includes content that regularly critiques democrats, generally offers support for republicans and the administration, and offers conservative perspectives on policy including consistent support for restrictive immigration policy. HYPOTHESES H1 Fox News Conservatizing Effects on Attitudes and Opinions While we anticipate heterogeneous effects as noted below, we expect overall main effects of Fox News based on the prior work demonstrating effects of Fox News on republican vote. Specifically because of the conservative nature of commentary on Fox News’ opinion programming like Tucker Carlson Tonight which fairly consistently critiques Democrats, supports Republicans and the administration, and offers conservative perspectives on policies like immigration we hypothesize that: H1A. Exposure to Fox News will influence evaluations of leaders and parties We expect that exposure to Fox News programming will lead individuals to feel more positively disposed toward Donald Trump and the Republican Party and more negatively disposed toward the Democratic Party. H1B. Exposure to Fox News will cause individuals to bring their policy views closer in line with those espoused on the programs they view. We expect that exposure to Fox News programming will lead individuals to express move conservative views toward the policies that are a focus of the programming watched (e.g. more support for restrictive immigration policy, more skepticism toward the Mueller investigation if those topics are a focus of the program on night of study). H1C. Exposure to Fox News will make individuals say the scope of government should be restricted. Given the general conservative slant of Carlson’s program, we expect exposure to Fox News programming will lead individuals to be more likely to say the scope of government should be restricted. H2. Dosage Effects We expect Fox News effects will be larger for those assigned to watch more Fox programming compared to those assigned to watch less Fox programming. H3. Heterogeneous Effects To understand who is effected by Fox News exposure, we also examine our effects separately by strength of partisanship and racial resentment. We have some expectation of differential influence based on how the content interacts with an individual’s prior views. Specifically, we expect stronger partisans will either be encountering information consistent with their perspectives and thus it is merely reinforcing or encountering counter-partisan information which motivated reasoning may lead them to reject. This will limit effects among strong partisans. Thus we expect it is those with weak partisan attachments and independents who are most influenced. H3A. Fox News Effects will be strongest among those with weak partisan attachments. Based on our own prior work and Zaller, we expect that those with weaker partisan attachments and independents will be more open to persuasion. Thus we expect Fox News Effects to be stronger among those with weak partisan attachments. H3B. Fox News Effects will be stronger among those high on racial resentment. The implicit racialized rhetoric that often see on Carlson’s program should be more persuasive among those high on racial resentment. We would particularly expect this if immigration is a key issue in the content during our study.
registration_responses.q17: Participants in our study will be randomly assigned to one of three conditions: Maximum Dosage Fox News Condition where watch Tucker Carlson Tonight for 30 minutes each night for three nights in a row; Minimum Dosage Fox News Condition where watch Tucker Carlson Tonight for 30 minutes one night and a Control Group where watch the Food Network Program Chopped for 30 minutes one night. Those in the Minimum Dosage and Control groups watch on what will be evening three for the Maximum Dosage condition. All groups then get the survey measuring our key outcome variables shortly after treatment that evening. To assess effects, our survey will ask participants their feelings about President Trump, the Republican and Democratic Parties, and their positions on a variety of policy issues (gun control, immigration, taxes, trade, and healthcare). We will include additional specific questions on issues that are the focus on the news cycle at the time of our study (specific questions decided on the day of the treatment to take advantage of the issues covered by the program in the week/on the day we administer the study). In addition, we will evaluate compliance with the treatment including questions on whether they watched on their assigned channel and a comprehension question about content that aired in the last five minutes of the programming they watched. [fn] Those in the maximum dosage condition will be sent a survey each night of the study. On nights 1 and 2 they will get only a very short survey focused on compliance evaluation.[/fn] By comparing responses of those assigned to watch more Fox News with those assigned to watch less Fox News, and by comparing responses of those assigned to watch any Fox News with those not assigned to watch any Fox, we will have estimates of the Fox News Effect in general, and the extent to which the effect is moderated by dosage amount. Our expectations, based on prior work, are that any exposure to Fox News will cause subjects to feel more positively disposed toward Donald Trump and the Republican Party, more negatively disposed toward the Democratic Party and will bring their policy views closer in line with those espoused by the network. We expect that the effects will be larger for those assigned to watch more Fox News, compared to those assigned to watch less. We also examine heterogeneous effects based on strength of partisanship and racial resentment. We expect stronger effects among weak partisans and independents and among those higher in racial resentment. We will measure effects both in an Intent-to-Treat framework, whereby we do not account for compliance, and as a function of compliance, where we focus only on those we believe successfully complied with their assignment. The size of the effects will likely depend on the content that airs the nights we field the study, which of course we cannot control. To account for this we will have a larger battery of policy questions related to the issues featured that evening added once we know the content of the program. Eligibility and exclusion criteria for participants Participants will be U.S. residents age 18 and older who are workers on Mechanical Turk who report access to both the Fox News Channel and the Food Network in our wave 1 recruitment survey and who agree to take part in the study. Our target sample size is 450 per condition. To reach this sample size we will initially recruit 3000 participants with our recruitment survey (to ensure we have enough individuals with access to cable who then agree to participate when invited into the study). We stratify on Party ID before random assignment to condition. Participants are recruited through MTurk, encouraged to uptake the media treatments through messages inviting those randomly assigned to a given treatment to participate in the study and providing details on their treatment assignment. The treatments are effectively administered in participants own homes or wherever they access cable. The surveys assessing compliance and measuring our key outcome variables hosted on the Qualtrics online survey platform and the invitation to complete the survey is sent approximately 30 minutes after end of the treatment assignment. Additional information including measurement of outcome variables (survey questions), statistical analyses, modeling and hypotheses testing is in the attached pre-analysis plan.

attributes.title: The Effect of Small Group Instruction in Mathematics for Pupils in Lower Elementary School

q1.value: The Effect of Small Group Instruction in Mathematics for Pupils in Lower Elementary School

q2.value: Henning Finseraas | Hans Bonesrønning | Ines Hardoy | Jon Marius Vaag Iversen | Ole Henning Nyhus | Vibeke Opheim | Kari Vea Salvanes | Astrid Marie Jorde Sandsør | Pål Schøne

q8.value: Registration prior to realization of outcomes

q15.value: We conduct a randomized controlled trial where schools in the treatment group receive resources to hire an additional teacher to teach mathematics in small groups of pupils in lower elementary school. The project includes 163 schools from ten municipalities, where 80 schools hire an additional teacher. Schools are randomized to treatment or control groups using stratified randomization. The project runs for four school years, with cross-cohort variation in the intensity and timing of treatment. The outcome variable is test scores in the national tests in fifth grade.

q16.value: We hypothesize that small group instructions increase math test scores. We examine treatment heterogeneity according to baseline ability and gender.

q17.value: Regression models with strata and cohort fixed effects. Standard errors are clustered at school level.

q19.value: 163 schools, 80 schools in the treatment group. Data are collected at the individual level (see PAP)

q24.value: Approval from the Norwegian Centre for Research Data (NSD)

q8.value: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

q15.value: It’s commonly observed that Americans believe crime is increasing, despite the large decreases in crime over the last two decades. This survey experiment tests if manipulating Americans’ perceptions of crime causes changes in punitive attitudes towards the criminal justice system. The two treatments groups are shown different graphs about crime, one portraying increasing crime and the other decreasing crime. The outcome questions all probe various aspects of punitive attitudes towards the criminal justice system, like support for the death penalty or making prison sentences longer

q16.value: Do people given the increased crime treatment have more punitive attitudes towards the criminal justice system, relative to the control condition? And do people given the reduced crime treatment have less punitive attitudes relative to the control?

q17.value: OLS regression with randomization inference based multiple comparisons correction.

registration_responses.q8: Registration prior to researcher analysis of outcome data

attributes.title: Anxiety Among Marginalized Groups Most Prone to Anxiousness and What it Means for Politics

q1.value: Anxiety Among Marginalized Groups Most Prone to Anxiousness and What it Means for Politics

q5.value: A special thanks to my chair Tom Nelson and committee members William Minozzi, Tom Wood, and Mike Neblo for their support, understanding, and commitment to seeing my project through to completion., Furthermore, thank you to the political psychology workshop in the department at Ohio State for comments and feedback, along with a discussant and commenters at the 2019 annual MPSA meeting.

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: Previous studies theorize a de-politicized thought process under the influence of anxiety, where cognitive biases like heuristics are inhibited from coloring political decision making. Furthermore, the results of these studies indicate anxiety can often be beneficial for the anxious, leading individuals to engage in normatively positive behaviors they might not otherwise engage in absent their anxiety. But anxiety is not always normatively warranted or personally beneficial. Consider African Americans living in urban areas and welfare (food stamp and Medicaid) recipients. Government policy (or politics more generally) can be at the root of or cause much of their anxiety. Members of these groups are chronically taxed by politics, which rewires neural networks in the brain and which leaves them with less available mental bandwidth to conduct themselves civically and politically; and they are more likely to have lower internal loci of control and self-esteem. Taken together, members of marginalized groups will respond differently to anxiety inducing primes than members of non-marginalized groups. While members of non-marginalized groups will respond to these primes with increased participation, members of marginalized groups will respond to these same primes with the opposite. I design three survey experiments to test the relationship between political anxiety and a variety of psychological, political, and normatively relevant outcomes. Experiments 1 and 2 are iterations of the same experiment. The first iteration is for African Americans. Half the sample will be African American and the remaining half will be white. The second iteration is for welfare recipients. Half the sample will be wealthy Americans and the other half will be welfare recipients. I will induce anxiety by having respondents first read portions of a recent news article about the increasing likelihood of nuclear war. I will follow this article by priming anxiety the way Albertson and Gadarian (2015) do. They utilize a process called thought listing, asking respondents to write down in open-ended form what makes them anxious about a pre-selected topic. Subjects randomly assigned to the control group will be asked to read about a non-political topic, like dog ownership, and engage in a thought listing exercise about it. All subjects will then answer a survey. Experiment 3 differs from Experiments 1 and 2 in that it matches each marginalized group with a prime specific to that group's political and social anxieties. The first part primes anxiety for the police to an African American sample only. The second part primes anxiety for cuts to the social safety net to welfare recipients. All subjects will then answer the same survey.

q16.value: H1: Moderately anxious group members will be the most likely to participate. The least and most anxious group members will be the least likely to participate. H2: Anxiety levels among members of marginalized groups will increase at a higher rate due to treatment. H2.1: Members of marginalized groups will exhibit a lower [higher] internal [external] locus of control than members of non-marginalized groups. H2.2: Anxious members of marginalized groups will exhibit a lower [higher] internal [external] locus of control than non-anxious members of marginalized groups. H2.3: Anxious members of marginalized groups will exhibit lower levels of self-esteem than anxious members of non-marginalized groups. H2.4: Anxious members of marginalized groups exhibiting the lowest levels of self-esteem will be the least likely to vote, and will express the lowest levels of trust and efficacy. H3: Marginalized group members will have lower levels of civic engagement than the non-marginalized. H4: Marginalized group members will have lower levels of civic self confidence than the non-marginalized.

q17.value: After operationalizing and executing my three survey experiments, I will perform the usual and customary statistical tests, including building linear regression models (OLS) and difference-in-means tests (T-tests). Because my research design utilizes experimental data rather observational data, and because randomization into a treatment group versus a control group allows me to assert causality to my treatment, I do not need complex methodological tests to assess support for my hypotheses. See the pre-analysis plan for further elaboration.

q19.value: Experiment 1: 400 subjects; Experiment 2: 400 subjects; Experiment 3: 400 subjects. Total subjects = 1200
